column1: My Man Godfrey is a 1936 American screwball comedy film directed by Gregory La Cava and starring William Powell and Carole Lombard
column2: who had been briefly married years before appearing together in the film. The screenplay for My Man Godfrey was written by Morrie Ryskind
column3: with uncredited contributions by La Cava
column5: a short novel by Eric S. Hatch. The story concerns a socialite who hires a derelict to be her family's butler
column6: and then falls in love with him.

column2: the original version of My Man Godfrey was deemed "culturally significant" by the United States Library of Congress and selected for preservation in the National Film Registry. The film was remade in 1957 with June Allyson and David Niven in the starring roles.
Godfrey "Smith" Parke is living with other men down on their luck at a New York City dump in a Hooverville on the East River near the 59th Street Bridge. One night
column3: a spoiled socialite named Cornelia Bullock offers him $5 to be her "forgotten man" for a scavenger hunt. Annoyed
column5: causing her to retreat and fall on a pile of ashes. She leaves in a fury
column6: much to the glee of her younger sister and rival
column8: Godfrey finds her to be kind
column9: though a bit scatter-brained. He offers to go with her to help her beat Cornelia.

column1: In the ballroom of the Waldorf-Ritz Hotel
column2: Irene's long-suffering businessman father Alexander Bullock waits resignedly as his ditsy wife Angelica and her mooching protégé Carlo play the game. Godfrey arrives and is authenticated as a "forgotten man". He then addresses the crowd
column3: expressing his contempt for their antics. Irene is apologetic and offers him a job as the family butler

column1: Godfrey is shown what to do by the Bullocks' wise-cracking maid Molly. She warns him that he is merely the latest in a long line of butlers. Godfrey proves to be surprisingly competent and resourceful. Irene considers him her protégé
column2: but Cornelia holds a grudge against him.

column6: but breaks down in tears and flees after being congratulated by Godfrey.

column2: Tommy is curious to know what one of the elite "Parkes of Boston" is doing as a servant. Godfrey explains that a broken love affair left him considering suicide
column3: but the undaunted attitude of the men living at the dump rekindled his spirits.

column1: Irene breaks her engagement to Charlie. Cornelia plants her pearl necklace under his mattress

column4: distressing Cornelia. Mr. Bullock realizes his daughter has orchestrated the whole thing. He informs Cornelia she had better find her uninsured pearls.

The film was based on a 1935 novel by Eric S. Hatch. Charles Rogers
column3: called it "a sure-fire laugh-getting novel". That studio purchased the film rights and assigned Hatch to write the script with Morrie Ryskind
column4: who received top billing for the screenplay. Rogers hired Gregory La Cava to direct

column1: It was the first major film from Universal after that studio had been taken over by new management
column2: including head of production Charles Rogers. However the studio did not have any major stars under contract apart from Buck Jones
column3: Boris Karloff and Edward Everett Horton
column4: and needed to borrow some from other studios.The studio's original choice to play Irene
column5: the part eventually played by Carole Lombard

column13: accompanied her. Alice Brady joined the cast in March.

column1: My Man Godfrey was in production from April 15 to May 27
column3: and then had retakes in early June of the year. Its budget was $575
column7: 645. The film was one of the first under the new regime of Charles Rogers at Universal
column8: although it had been developed under his predecessor Carl Laemmle Jnr.La Cava
column9: a former animator and freelancer for most of his film career

SEE YOU TOMORROW."Due to insurance considerations a stand-in stuntman (Chick Collins) was used when Godfrey carried Irene over his shoulder up the stairs to her bedroom.When tensions hit a high point on the set
column16: Lombard had a habit of inserting four letter words into her dialogue
column17: often to the great amusement of the cast. This made shooting somewhat difficult
column18: but clips of her cursing in her dialogue and messing up her lines can still be seen in blooper reels.

column1: It was the first film released under the aegis of Charles Rogers and was given a big premiere. My Man Godfrey premiered on September 6
column3: and was released in the United States on the 17th of September. It was a runaway hit and earned huge profits for the studio.The movie was one of the most acclaimed comedies of 1936. Writing for The Spectator in 1936
column4: Graham Greene gave the film a moderately positive review
column5: characterizing it as "acutely funny [for three-quarters of its way]". Particularly praising the scene of the scavenging party
column6: Greene finds it to be "perhaps the wittiest
column8: sequence of the year". Considering the end of the film
column10: he notes that "the social conscience is a little confused" and he wishes for a more "dignified exit".

column1: My Man Godfrey was the first movie to be nominated in all four acting categories
column2: in the first year that supporting categories were introduced. It's also the only film in Oscar history to receive a nomination in all four acting categories and not be nominated for Best Picture
column3: and was the only film to be nominated in these six categories and not receive any award until 2013's American Hustle.In 1999
column4: the film was deemed "culturally significant" by the United States Library of Congress and selected for preservation in the National Film Registry. In 2000
column5: the film was ranked #44 on the American Film Institute's list of the 100 funniest comedies
column6: and Premiere voted it one of "The 50 Greatest Comedies Of All Time" in 2006. Rotten Tomatoes gives it a score of 100% with an average rating of 8.3/10 with the consensus stating: "A class satire in a class of its own
column7: My Man Godfrey's screwball comedy is as sharp as the social commentary is biting."

column1: The original film is generally thought to have lapsed into the public domain due to a failure to renew the film's copyright after 28 years. However the underlying work
column2: the 1935 book 1101 Park Avenue – re-titled My Man Godfrey with the film's release – had its copyright renewed in 1963 and is thus still in copyright. According to Stanford University Library
column3: and under rulings of Stewart v. Abend
column5: the rights holder of the original work can claim ownership of the film script
column7: if the original book is still in copyright. "Films are often based on books .. that may maintain copyright. If the pre-existing work is protected
column9: it has generally been determined that the derived film is also protected."

column2: a restored print was made available on DVD by The Criterion Collection. In 2005
column3: 20th Century Fox Home Video released a colorized version.
